content: The "Federal Workforce Reduction and Realignment Commission Act" establishes an independent commission to reduce the number of Federal employees by 250,000 in non-defense-related agencies, aiming to improve Government efficiency. The Commission, composed of 8 members appointed by the President with Senate approval, must have nominations submitted within 30 days of the Act's enactment. The President consults with various congressional leaders for selecting Commission members. The Commission, consisting of 8 members appointed by the President with Senate approval, must have nominations submitted within 30 days. The President consults with congressional leaders for selecting members. The appointed Chairman designates 1 member. Each member serves for the life of the Commission, with meetings called by the Chairman or majority members. Meetings are open to the public, and members are paid at a specified rate for their duties. The Commission can appoint personnel and set their pay, with a limit on the number of personnel from Federal agencies. Reporting requirements are also specified. The Commission must submit a report to the President and Congress within 90 days of appointment, containing recommendations on legislation and methodology. The President must then approve or disapprove the recommendations within 10 days, with the option to suggest changes to the Commission. The Commission must submit a report to the President and Congress within 90 days of appointment, with recommendations on legislation and methodology. The President can suggest changes to the Commission within 10 days, which then has an additional 10 days to consider and submit the final report to Congress. SEC. 7. CONGRESSIONAL CONSIDERATION OF COMMISSION REPORT. Terms of the Resolution for the joint resolution under this Act include specific requirements such as no preamble, a set format for the resolving clause, and a designated title. Resolutions introduced in the House of Representatives will be referred accordingly. The House of Representatives refers resolutions to the Committee on Post Office and Civil Service, while the Senate refers them to the Committee on Governmental Affairs. If a resolution is not reported within 20 days, the committee is discharged, and the resolution is placed on the House calendar for consideration. If a resolution is not reported within 20 days, the committee is discharged, and the resolution is placed on the House calendar for consideration. Any Member can move to proceed to the consideration of the resolution, which is privileged and not debatable. The motion is not subject to amendment or postponement. If agreed to, the respective House shall immediately proceed to consider the joint resolution without delay. Debate on the resolution is limited to 2 hours, divided equally between supporters and opponents. No amendments are allowed, but a motion to further limit debate is permitted. Postponement, consideration of other business, or recommitting the resolution is not allowed. A motion to reconsider the vote is also not permitted. Following the debate, a single quorum call is requested. The rules for debate and voting on a resolution are outlined, including limitations on debate time, amendments, and motions. Appeals on rule application are decided without debate. Procedures for consideration by the other House are specified, with restrictions on referral to committees and consideration except for final passage. Upon disposition of the resolution received from the other House, it shall no longer be in order to consider the resolution that originated in the receiving House. This section is enacted by Congress as part of the rules of each House, applicable only with respect to the procedure to be followed. This section supersedes other rules only to the extent that it is inconsistent with them, recognizing the constitutional right of each House to change its rules regarding procedure at any time. SEC. 8. TERMINATION. The Commission will end when it submits its final report under section 6(b)(2).
